Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Film MicroStereoLithography for Microlens Fabrication
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to create an innovative technology to manufacture micro-lenses and other micro-optical components, which have a wide variety of applications in areas of telecommunications, precision optics, imaging and display devices, etc., Success in the optics marketplace depends on the ability to introduce newer products in shorter times. Existing micro-lens manufacturing processes have little flexibility and are very expensive for prototype testing and tooling for mass manufacturing. The objective of this project is to develop an intelligent fabrication technology with high flexibility to reduce product development time and cost for micro-lenses by up to 30%. The project will develop a strong scientific understanding of photopolymerization and will achieve high fidelity control over the fabrication process. The project will use a Film Micro-Stereolithography process (FMSL), which uses a computer controlled digital mask to cure photopolymer resin into micro-lenses, by accurately controlling the exposure. Research efforts will focus on improving the FMSL optics system, constructing high fidelity models of resin response, and formulating an improved process planning algorithm. As a result, an intelligent flexible manufacturing process to fabricate high quality reliable micro-lenses will be developed.

The commercial potential of this project is two-fold: it will aid in faster introduction of innovative imaging and telecommunication devices to the market place; and will provide the intellectual foundation for improving micro-fabrication processes for the entire Micro-Opto-Electro-Mechanical systems industry. Of the many micro-fabrication technologies which cater to the micro-optics industry, none addresses the growing need to reduce prototyping cost and time associated with fabricating micro-lenses. The FMSL process has a significant potential to provide high manufacturing flexibility along with reduced production cost and time. The enhanced intellectual foundation can be extended to serve industries other than micro-lens arrays. These include fabrication of micro-fluidic channels and micro-optic components on a curved base, which can have applications in fields of drug delivery, surveillance and clean energy. FMSL is an advanced single step additive manufacturing technology that eliminates wasted raw materials, since virtually all raw materials are converted into the final product, and that is environmentally friendly, since no hazardous chemicals are needed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this Phase-I research project was to develop a fabrication process to manufacture customized microlenses and microlens arrays. These devices have a wide variety of applications in areas of telecommunications, precision optics, imaging and display devices, etc. Success in the optics marketplace today depends on the ability to introduce newer products with ever-shorter lead times. Existing microlens manufacturing processes have little flexibility and are very expensive for prototype testing and low production volumes. The objective of this Phase I project was to demonstrate feasibility for fabricating custom microlenses with high flexibility, reduced product development time and lower overall fabrication cost.

 A key result of this project was our development of the Exposure Controlled Projection Lithography (ECPL) process, which is an intelligent precision fabrication process that incorporates the science of photopolymerization kinetics and high-fidelity optics into process planning software that guides the fabrication of microlenses from photopolymer resins. The material parameters of the photocurable resin are obtained after studying the fundamentals of the photopolymerization process. These parameters are then fed in into the process planning software as inputs. By carrying out multi-objective optimization within the process plan, an accurate exposure scheme for each resin composition can be developed. This exposure profile is then precisely projected on the resin surface using a computer controlled gray-scale projection mask, which ultimately results in generation of the three-dimensional cured shape of the object being fabricated.

 We have developed a scientific foundation for understanding the photopolymerization process which aids in efficiently controlling the ECPL process by modeling and conducting a high fidelity simulations using a commercial finite element simulation software package. For purposes of developing a manufacturing process plan for commercial applications, we also built an empirical meta-model based on experimental results. This empirical model was later used to develop the manufacturing process plan.

We also successfully developed a working software module which translates desired lens design parameters into appropriate inputs for driving the ECPL process. Several microlenses were fabricated by this method and characterized. Feasibility for fabricating lenses from the ECPL system with diameters ranging from 100µm to 10mm in diameter was successfully demonstrated.

In order to transform the experimental ECPL system into a mature fabrication process, a real-time interferometric cure monitoring system was designed and added to the existing ECPL system hardware. It was demonstrated that this system could be utilized for real-time monitoring of the full range of chemical processes that occur during a photopolymerization experiment.  This system therefore provides a powerful tool to assist in real-time control of the growth of microlenses in the ECPL system. We plan to develop new, more streamlined software with an intuitive user-interface to convert lens specifications into appropriate fabrication parameters to drive the ECPL system hardware with integrated feedback control.
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this Phase-I research project was to develop a fabrication process to manufacture customized microlenses and microlens arrays. These devices have a wide variety of applications in areas of telecommunications, precision optics, imaging and display devices, etc. Success in the optics marketplace today depends on the ability to introduce newer products with ever-shorter lead times. Existing microlens manufacturing processes have little flexibility and are very expensive for prototype testing and low production volumes. The objective of this Phase I project was to demonstrate feasibility for fabricating custom microlenses with high flexibility, reduced product development time and lower overall fabrication cost. A key result of this project was our development of the Exposure Controlled Projection Lithography (ECPL) process, which is an intelligent precision fabrication process that incorporates the science of photopolymerization kinetics and high-fidelity optics into process planning software that guides the fabrication of microlenses from photopolymer resins. The material parameters of the photocurable resin are obtained after studying the fundamentals of the photopolymerization process. These parameters are then fed in into the process planning software as inputs. By carrying out multi-objective optimization within the process plan, an accurate exposure scheme for each resin composition can be developed. This exposure profile is then precisely projected on the resin surface using a computer controlled gray-scale projection mask, which ultimately results in generation of the three-dimensional cured shape of the object being fabricated. We have developed a scientific foundation for understanding the photopolymerization process which aids in efficiently controlling the ECPL process by modeling and conducting a high fidelity simulations using a commercial finite element simulation software package. For purposes of developing a manufacturing process plan for commercial applications, we also built an empirical meta-model based on experimental results. This empirical model was later used to develop the manufacturing process plan. We also successfully developed a working software module which translates desired lens design parameters into appropriate inputs for driving the ECPL process. Several microlenses were fabricated by this method and characterized. Feasibility for fabricating lenses from the ECPL system with diameters ranging from 100µm to 10mm in diameter was successfully demonstrated. In order to transform the experimental ECPL system into a mature fabrication process, a real-time interferometric cure monitoring system was designed and added to the existing ECPL system hardware. It was demonstrated that this system could be utilized for real-time monitoring of the full range of chemical processes that occur during a photopolymerization experiment. This system therefore provides a powerful tool to assist in real-time control of the growth of microlenses in the ECPL system. We plan to develop new, more streamlined software with an intuitive user-interface to convert lens specifications into appropriate fabrication parameters to drive the ECPL system hardware with integrated feedback control. Intellectual property developed during the course of this project is currently protected in form of two separate patent applications. A research paper highlighting the monitoring system was presented at this yearÆs Solid Freeform Conference, and we plan to refine the paper further for submission to a peer-reviewed journal in the field. The details of the novel control methods for driving the ECPL process will be released for publication at an upcoming SPIE conference in early 2012. This SBIR Phase-I funding has helped the Company secure matching funds from the State of Georgia for further maturation of its business and technology.
